title: How I Got My First Article Curated on Medium
html:

How I Got My First Article Curated on Medium

Hint: I didn’t plan on it.

Ethan Hawley
Mar 27
Expecting is the greatest impediment to living. In anticipation of tomorrow, it loses today. — Seneca

I’ve been a member of Medium, on and off, for about one year. During my first go, I had published around one-hundred articles that mainly dealt with topics like meditation, mindfulness, and philosophy. Most of those pieces reflected my personal interests, as well as extracurricular research assignments connected with my pursuit of certification to teach meditation professionally.

While publishing here, I made a few bucks as well as receiving the added bonus, which I think most Medium writers and readers would agree, of being part of something special — the Medium community. For me, this represents a safe place to publish pretty much anything I want and a platform which offers an extensive variety of amazing writers whose honest accounts of their life experiences make me feel just a little bit better about my own.

When my meditation studies concluded, I deleted all my articles and closed up shop without feeling the need to say goodbye. I just wanted some time off to regroup and attend to some things in my life before staging a writing comeback.

As soon as the time was right, I wrote and published Observations From Making $65,000 a Month to Under $500 followed on the same day by I Can Forgive. But Can I Ever Forget?

Those stories received 59 combined views and 23 fans. Neither one of them were selected by the Medium curators.

The truth is, even though I checked off the little box under the tags section, I never read these new curation guidelines. Not once did I expect that either one of those pieces would be selected.

My mindset remained on the pre-curation days and I interpreted those humble, initial stats as par for the course.

Then, I wrote and published an article about Trump:

For the first day or so, the views and fans trickled in at more or less the same pace as my previous, two articles.

When I checked my stats again (I don’t remember exactly if it was the next morning or a day after that) I thought the system had a glitch.

I was about to email Medium support until it finally clicked that my article was selected by one or more curators to be distributed in both Philosophy and Politics.

Since then, I’ve had only two other articles curated, but the Trump one, by far, has the most views and fans.

HOW I MANAGED TO GET THE ARTICLE CURATED

I DIDN’T PLAN ON CURATION

I believe I already covered that.

I WASN’T LOOKING TO SHOCK PEOPLE JUST FOR VIEWS

I’m well aware of how sensitive people are to Trump, but when you read the article I only mention him once by pointing out that his “unorthodox shenanigans are extremely entertaining.” That’s some watered down, NPR-vanilla-pudding Trump coverage.

I WROTE WITH HONESTY

I wrote what came from my honest opinion about the state of our union. In other words, my writing didn’t feel forced or contrived. I’m not a political expert nor a fan of politics, and I was mindful to point that out.

I DIDN’T USE GRAMMARLY

After about a week, one reader was kind enough to send me a private message about a few grammatical errors I had made. In retrospect, the curator(s) had missed those.

THERE ARE NO EXTERNAL LINKS OR REFERENCES

I didn’t do any research, aside from looking up a Pete Davidson quote. I also just noticed that I didn’t even cite or give credit to the photographer — Oops!

I KEPT IT SHORT

The article has only 555 words.

CONCLUSION

Curation is a wonderful bonus for any writer looking to garner more fans, followers, and money. As far as I can gather, it also appears to be the quickest route for new writers to make Medium their sole platform for earning a living.

It’s only natural, if that’s your objective, to then decipher the system and come up with a template you can use again and again to increase your odds at getting curated.

I don’t have that template.

What I have garnered is that before my article was curated, the experience writing it, without worry, without following some kind of strategy, and by writing with total honesty just felt real, damn good.

  • Medium
  • Writing
  • Creativity
  • Productivity
  • Writing Tips

  • Ethan Hawley

    Medium member since Mar 2019

    Pursuing opportunities without regard to resources currently controlled.

  • The Writing Cooperative

    Helping each other write better.
content_html:
